title: How on earth does someone write a 10,000 word essay on something? - Quora

response.answer_text: 10,000 words is about 40 pages. That is too long for something that is actually just an “essay” (ie your own thoughts and ideas on a subject. If it’s a research paper on a topic you are an expert in, it could be a master’s thesis or senior thesis as the culmination of an undergrad course of study. If a professor at the undergrad level is just casually handing out an assignment to write 10,000 words, without careful guidelines, it is an invitation to padding or outright plagiarism. It would take most people a couple of months to write a thoughtful and intelligent 40 page paper. I just looked at a paper I wrote as an undergrad—it was a “Directed Readings” course, meaning that for a whole summer, this is all I worked on. I went to the Boston Public Library to find sources. My Works Cited page has 22 items, all of them books, and I had read substantial parts of most of them. It is 41 pages long, plus 4 pages of notes and 2 pages of bibliography. Writing it was the entire 3-credit course. I wrote it up by hand and then typed it on a manual typewriter on “corresable paper.” (The year was 1972.) It would be a little easier today, but it is still a very large project. My topic was the poetry of Gerard Manley Hopkins. I learned a lot! But I would not call it “an essay.”

By doing one, typed, polished page per day. Each page has about 350 words. That would let you produce a 10,000 word essay in 28.5 days, if you write one page every single day. Frankly, that’s not so bad as it sounds.. As an English major, I’d typically produce three or four papers of that length every semester when you added up all my senior-level undergraduate and graduate-level courses thirty years ago. I’d also add it’s harder to write something short, polished, and concise of 10 solid pages than it is to write something bloated of 28 or 30 pages. In your comment to the question, you say that can’t imagine having to write more than a hundred words on a topic. However, in that same comment to your question, you wrote a total of 59 words. I bet you produced that 59 word question in less than ten minutes. If you wrote for an hour and a half, that would be about 600 words (or two pages). That’s already a few percent of the way toward a 10,000 word-essay.

You start with single word, at that point one more and again, and before you know it, you have 10 000 words. This may sound peculiar to you, yet it is the key to composing such enormous volume papers. In the event that you begin considering the size of the errand, you will never at any point start it or complete it. Truth be told, composing a paper of 10 000 words is no cakewalk. Yet, you can finish it with devotion and by utilizing the correct system. Your issue with such a huge undertaking is likely the absence of time and scholastic assets……

I once wrote a 45,000 word essay. It was my doctoral dissertation. The size of the project was intimidating until I realized that I only needed to write nine chapters each 20 pages long. And a 20 page paper was something I had done lots of times. So the key is to break the project down into smaller, less intimidating pieces
If you can write 500 words, you can write 10,000 words. Every subject can be subdivided into smaller and smaller segments, each of which can be explained in detail.
